questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fossa of Rosenmuller The image shown is the endoscopic view of lateral wall of nasopharynx amd the marked structure is fossa of rosenmuller. Fossa of Rosenmüller is the commonest site for the origin of carcinoma nasopharynx.

Highyeild:

STRUCTURES SEEN IN NASOPHARYNX Pharyngeal opening of eustachian tube. Torus tubarius- elevation present behind the opening of eustachian tube. Fossa of rosenmuller- Lateral pharyngeal recess which is present above and behind torus tubarius. It is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Adenoids/Nasopharyngeal tonsil. Passavant’s ridge.

questions.text: A patient presented with a change in voice. He was diagnosed with cancer and underwent an intervention. Following which surgery is the following intervention done?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Total laryngectomy Above image shows post operative tracheal stump created for breathing in patients who underwent total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma.

Highyeild:

Total laryngectomy is indicated in the following conditions: T3 lesions (i.e. with cord fixed) All T4 lesions Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement Lesions of posterior commissure Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery Transglottic cancers, i.e. tumours involving supraglottis and glottis across the ventricle, causing fixation of the vocal cord. It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Partial laryngectomy involves excision of vocal cord and anterior commissure region in partial front lateral laryngectomy and excision of supraglottis in partial horizontal laryngectomy. OPTION C- Post op tracheal stump is not needed in patients with vertical hemilaryngectomy. OPTION D- Post op tracheal stump is not needed in patients with horizontal hemilaryngectomy.

Extraedge:

In Total laryngectomy The entire larynx including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles and one or more rings of trachea are removed. Pharyngeal wall is repaired and lower tracheal stump sutured to the skin for breathing.

questions.text: Patient had negative rinne on 256 and 512 Hz tuning fork but positive rinne on 1024 Hz. What is the air bone gap?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

30-45 Db Rinne negative at 256 hz and 512 hz and positive rinne at 1024 hz indicates air and bone conduction gap of 30-45 dB.

Highyeild:

Rinne’s test In this test air conduction of the ear is compared with its bone conduction. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the meatus. If he still hears, AC is more than BC. Alternatively, the patient is asked to compare the loudness of sound heard through air and bone conduction. Rinne test is called positive when AC is longer or louder than BC. It is seen in normal persons or those having sensorineural deafness. A negative Rinne (BC > AC) is seen in conductive deafness. A negative Rinne indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 15–20 dB. A prediction of air-bone gap can be made if tuning forks of 256, 512 and 1024 Hz are used. A Rinne test equal or negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates air-bone gap of 20–30 dB. A Rinne test negative for 256 and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates air-bone gap of 30–45 dB. A Rinne negative for all the three tuning forks of 256, 512 and 1024 Hz indicates air-bone gap of 45–60 dB.

Extraedge:

TUNING FORK TESTS AND THEIR INTERPRETATION Test Normal Conductive deafness SN deafness Rinne AC > BC (Rinne positive) BC AC (Rinne negative) AC > BC Weber Not lateralized Lateralized to poorer ear Lateralized to better ear ABC Same as examiner's Same as examiner's Reduced Schwabach Equal Lengthened Shortened

questions.text: Identify the cancer in this HIV positive patient with CD4 count <150
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kaposi’s sarcoma Given image is of kaposi sarcoma.

Highyeild:

KAPOSI SARCOMA It is a vascular tumour, multifocal in origin, primarily affecting skin but may occur in the oral cavity. Its incidence is high in AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) patients. The lesion appears as a reddish purple nodule or a plaque mostly on the palate. Microscopically, it consists of spindle cells with haemorrhagic cleft-like spaces. Treatment is not satisfactory. Kaposi sarcoma in non-AIDS patients may respond to chemotherapy but its response in patients suffering from AIDS is poor In the oral cavity, Kaposi sarcoma is mostly seen in the palate, but may occur on the tongue or gingiva or on the posterior wall of the pharynx. It appears purplish in colour and may need to be differentiated from angioma or pyogenic granuloma. It can occur at any stage of HIV infection, even in those with normal CD4 counts.

questions.text: A 3 year old child presented with fever and biphasic stridor
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis Above image shows steeple sign which is seen in croup/acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

Highyeild:

ACUTE LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS It is an inflammatory condition of the larynx, trachea and bronchi; more common than acute epiglottitis. it is viral infection (parainfluenza type I and II) affecting children between 6 months and 3 years of age. Disease starts as upper respiratory infection with hoarse- ness and croupy cough. There is fever of 39–40 °C. This may be followed by difficulty in breathing and inspira- tory type of stridor. Respiratory difficulty may gradually increase with signs of upper airway obstruction, i.e suprasternal and intercostal recession. TREATMENT Hospitalisation Antibiotics Humidification Parenteral fluids Steroids, e.g. hydrocortisone 100 mg i.v. may be useful to relieve oedema. Adrenaline, racemic adrenaline administered via a respirator is a bronchodilator and may relieve dyspnoea and avert tracheostomy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B- In acute epiglottitis thumb sign is seen on x ray. OPTION C- In subglottic stenosis above x ray is not seen. OPTION D- Foreign body will be seen on x ray of foreign body obstruction.

questions.text: Patient has enlarged tonsils and is unable to swallow. Patient is also complaining of ear pain. Likely a source of ear pain?
questions.correct_answer: B. Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve The tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

Highyeild:

The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve. Therefore any irritation/pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve. Causes of referred otalgia via glossopharyngeal nerve acute tonsillitis acute pharyngitis peritonsillar abscess elongated styloid process.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Causes of referred pain via auricular branch of vagus nerve include malignancy or ulcerative lesion of vallecula, epiglottis, larynx. OPTION C- The greater auricular nerve provides sensory sensation for the lower two-thirds of the pinna. OPTION D- Mandibular nerve is not involved in the above mentioned question.

questions.text: A patient presented with progressive growing swelling from the last 2 years. On examination it was dense, mobile and nodular as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Parotid gland tumor The given clinical scenario and image depicts that it is a likely case of parotid tumor, likely to be a pleomorphic adenoma.

Highyeild:

PLEOMORPHIC ADENOMA It is the most common benign tumour of salivary glands. It can arise from the parotid, submandibular or other minor salivary glands. In the parotid it usually arises from its tail. It can also arise from the deep lobe of the parotid and present as a parapharyngeal tumour in the oropharynx. Pleomorphic adenomas are slow-growing tumours and may be quite large at initial presentation. They are usually seen in the third or fourth decade, with propensity for females. They are called “ mixed tumours ” because both epithelial and mesenchymal elements are seen in histol- ogy. The stroma of the tumour may be mucoid, fibroid, vascular, myxochondroid or chondroid and its proportion to the epithelial element may vary. Though tumour is encapsulated, it sends pseudopods into the surrounding gland which are left behind if the tumour is simply shelled out. It is therefore essential that surgical excision of the tumour should include normal gland tissue around it. In the parotid, it amounts to superficial parotidectomy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B- Jaw tumours are relatively rare growths or lesions that develop in the jawbone or the soft tissues in the mouth and face. OPTION C - Dermoid cysts are slow growing benign lesions. They are mostly seen on the scalp and skull. It is made up of hair, teeth, cartilage and skin glands. OPTION D- A sebaceous cyst is derived from hair follicle infundibulum or traumatic inclusion. The most common site of sebaceous cyst is postauricular sulcus or below or behind the ear lobule. It may ooze out foul smelling, cheese like discharge.

questions.text: A child had a head injury 1 year ago. Now the patient presented with non axial proptosis of the left eye. Identify the mass in a given scan?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Frontal mucocele Above image is of frontal mucocele.

Highyeild:

Mucocele of the frontal sinus usually presents in the superomedial quadrant of the orbit (90%) and displaces the eyeball forward, downward and laterally. The swelling is cystic and nontender; egg-shell crackling may be elicited. Sometimes, it presents as a cystic swelling in the forehead (10%). Patient’s complaints are usually mild and may include headache, diplopia and proptosis. Imaging of the frontal sinus usually reveals clouding of the sinus with loss of scalloped outline which is so typical of the normal frontal sinus . Treatment is frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of frontal sinus into the middle meatus. CT scan of mucocele of the left frontoethmoid region. Note the left eyeball has been displaced downwards and laterally (arrows) (different patient). Mucocele of frontal sinus. Note swelling above the medial canthus of left eye (arrow).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Orbital pseudotumor is the swelling of tissue behind the eye in an area called the orbit. The orbit is the hollow space in the skull where the eye sits. The orbit protects the eyeball and the muscles and tissue that surround it. Orbital pseudotumor does not spread to other tissues or places in the body. OPTION B- Ethmoid Meningioma is a well-recognized tumor of the central nervous system, but it rarely appears as a primary extracranial tumor ofthe paranasal sinuses. OPTION D -Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a rare tumour, though it is the commonest of all benign tumours of nasopharynx. Aetiology The exact cause is unknown. As the tumour is predominantly seen in adolescent males in the second decade of life, it is thought to be testosterone dependent.

questions.text: Tracheostomy tube is not indicated in?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unilateral abductor palsy Tracheostomy is not indicated in unilateral abductor palsy.

Highyeild:

INDICATIONS FOR TRACHEOSTOMY 1. Respiratory obstruction (a) Infections (i) Acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, acute epiglottitis, diphtheria (ii) Ludwig's angina, peritonsillar, retropharyngeal or parapharyngeal abscess, tongue abscess (b) Trauma (i) External injury of larynx and trachea (ii) Trauma due to endoscopies, especially in infants and children (iii) Fractures of mandible or maxillofacial injuries (c) Neoplasms (d) Foreign body larynx (e) Oedema larynx due to steam, irritant fumes or gases, allergy (angioneurotic or drug sensitivity), radiation (f) Bilateral abductor paralysis (g) Congenital anomalies Laryngeal web, cysts, tracheo-oesophageal fistula Bilateral choanal atresia 2. Retained secretions (a) Inability to cough (i) Coma of any cause, e.g. head injuries, cerebrovascular accidents, narcotic overdose (ii) Paralysis of respiratory muscles, e.g. spinal injuries, polio, Guillain-Barre syndrome, myasthenia gravis (iii) Spasm of respiratory muscles, tetanus, eclampsia, strychnine poisoning (b) Painful cough (c) Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions 3. Respiratory insufficiency Chronic lung conditions, viz. emphysema, chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis, atelectasis Conditions listed in A and B
